content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA contribution limits are based on the combined compensation of both spouses. The taxable year can be reduced by the deduction allowable to the spouse if filing a joint return with lower compensation. Amendments to section 219(f) limit the application to subsection (b). Amendments to section 408(d)(5) reduce the amount from $2,250 to $2,000. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free to buy first homes, pay for higher education or long-term care, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first home purchases, educational expenses, or long-term care. The new amendment defines qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments used for qualified acquisition costs for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence within 60 days of receipt. The new amendment defines qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement and closing costs. The term 'first-time homebuyer' refers to an individual, their spouse, child, or grandchild. The new amendment allows for qualified first-time homebuyer distributions if the individual had no ownership interest in a principal residence for 3 years prior to acquisition, and certain subsections of section 1034 did not suspend any period of time specified in section 1034. The term 'principal residence' in subparagraph (A)(ii) has the same meaning as in section 1034. The term 'date of acquisition' refers to the date a binding contract is entered into or construction of the principal residence begins. A special rule applies if there is a delay in acquisition from an individual retirement plan. If a distribution from an individual retirement plan fails to meet requirements due to a delay in purchasing or constructing a residence, the amount may be contributed to another plan within 120 days. This contribution is not subject to certain restrictions and does not affect the application of other rules. For qualified higher education expenses, specific criteria apply. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution. The amount of these expenses for a taxable year is reduced by any excludable amount under section 135. Qualified long-term care expenses are amounts paid for necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services, including personal care, required by an individual. This also includes insurance covering such services. Individuals who are functionally impaired can receive assistance with daily activities they are unable to perform, as prescribed by a licensed healthcare practitioner. Functionally impaired individuals are certified by a licensed healthcare practitioner as unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. Special rules apply for home health care services provided to individuals residing at home. The term 'licensed health care practitioner' includes physicians, registered nurses, and qualified community care case managers. The term 'qualified community care case manager' refers to an individual or entity with experience in providing case management services and preparing care plans. Penalty-Free Distributions for Certain Unemployed Individuals: Individuals must meet requirements prescribed by the Secretary and not be a relative of the individual receiving case management services. The term 'relative' is defined as an individual bearing a relationship described in specific sections. Penalty-Free Distributions for Unemployed Individuals: An amendment allows distributions from an individual retirement plan to individuals who have received 12 consecutive weeks of unemployment compensation after separation from employment. The distributions must be made during the taxable year in which the compensation is paid or the following year. An amendment to Section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) allows penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. Additionally, Section 403(b)(11) is amended to allow for these distributions. The amendment allows penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses under Section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) and Section 403(b)(11). The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act.
